    • roundDownByLargestPower

      public static float roundDownByLargestPower(float f)
      Round number down to in the largest power. For example, roundDownByLargestPower(3.1) returns 3.0 roundDownByLargestPower(-3.1) returns -4.0 roundDownByLargestPower(31.1) returns 30.0
      Parameters:
      f -
      Returns:

    • roundUpByLargestPower

      public static float roundUpByLargestPower(float f)
      Round number up to the next digit in the largest power. MiscMath.roundUpByLargestPower(31.1f) == 40.0f; MiscMath.roundUpByLargestPower(0.11f) == 1.0f; MiscMath.roundUpByLargestPower(-0.011f) == -0.02f; MiscMath.roundUpByLargestPower(310.1f) == 400.0f; MiscMath.roundUpByLargestPower(-3.1) == -4.0f; MiscMath.roundUpByLargestPower(3.1) == 4.0f;
      Parameters:
      f -
      Returns:

    • taylor

      protected static double taylor(double number, int n)
      use the taylor series to approximate the natural log of a number. Note that internally, the variable x which is number - 1. ln(1 + x) is computed, so number = 1 + x and therefore x = number - 1; ln(1+x) = x - (x^2)/2 + (x^3)/3 - ...
      Parameters:
      number -
      n -
      Returns:

    • computeNDivKTimesNMinusK

      public static long computeNDivKTimesNMinusK(int n, int k)
      compute n!/k!(n-k)!. Note that if n or k are larger than 12, computeNDivKTimesNMinusKBigInteger is used and in that case, if the result is larger than Long.MAX_VALUE, LONG.MAX_VALUE is returned.
      Parameters:
      n -
      k -
      Returns:

    • solveCubicRoots

      public static double[] solveCubicRoots(double a, double b, double c, double d)
      solve for the roots of equation a * x^3 + b * x^2 + c * x + d = 0; most of the method is adapted from http://www.csse.uwa.edu.au/~pk/research/matlabfns/Misc/cubicroots.m Copyright (c) 2008 Peter Kovesi School of Computer Science & Software Engineering The University of Western Australia pk at csse uwa edu au http://www.csse.uwa.edu.au/ Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal in the Software without restriction, subject to the following conditions: The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all copies or substantial portions of the Software. The Software is provided "as is", without warranty of any kind. Nov 2008
      Parameters:
      a - coeff for 3rd order
      b - coeff for 2nd order
      c - coeff for 1st order
      d - coeff for 0th order
      Returns:

    • realcuberoot

      public static double realcuberoot(double x)

    • chooseRandomly

      public static void chooseRandomly(Random rand, int[] selected, int nMax)
      choose selected.length unique random numbers between 0 and nMax and populate the array 'selected' with them. Note that the number of ways to make a subset of 7 distinct numbers out of nMax numbers is nMax!/(nMax-7)! So the probability of selecting the same 7 randomly from nMax is very low when nMax is much larger than selected.length, so this method does not check that the same 7 were not drawn before, but the invoker should for small nMax.
      Parameters:
      rand - class to generate semi random numbers
      selected - the output array to populate with unique random numbers valued 0 to nMax, exclusive.
      nMax - the upper limit from which to choose numbers from for 'selected', where the possible numbers are 0 through nMax-1.

    • findStrongPeakIndexes

      public static List<Integer> findStrongPeakIndexes(algorithms.misc.HistogramHolder h, float frac)
      for the given histogram, returns the indexes of the primary peak and any peaks which are larger than frac*maxPeak above their neighboring values.
      Parameters:
      h -
      frac - the fraction of the y value of the maximum peak that is used as a critical limit that any other peaks must have in excess of their neighboring points. For example, 0.1.
      Returns:

            |
            |
   180 ----------- 0

    • calculateCosineSimilarity

      public static float calculateCosineSimilarity(float[] a, float[] b, float sentinel)
      Calculate the cosine similarity between 2 descriptors. Calculates a dot b/(magnitude(a) * magnitude(b). The equation and use are from the paper "Generalized RANSAC framework for relaxed correspondence problems" by Zhang and Kosecka. The authors use the similarity with a threshold of 0.95 to filter out dissimilar matches.
      Parameters:
      a -
      b -
      sentinel -
      Returns:

    • calculateCosineSimilarity

      public static float calculateCosineSimilarity(int[] a, int[] b, int sentinel)
      Calculate the cosine similarity between 2 descriptors. Calculates a dot b/(magnitude(a) * magnitude(b). The equation and use are from the paper "Generalized RANSAC framework for relaxed correspondence problems" by Zhang and Kosecka. The authors use the similarity with a threshold of 0.95 to filter out dissimilar matches.
      Parameters:
      a -
      b -
      sentinel -
      Returns:

    • sumSquaredError

      public static float sumSquaredError(int[] a, int sentinel, int centralIdx)
      Determine the sum squared error within this array using auto-correlation and the assumption that the value at the middle index is the value from the original central pixel. Values the same as the sentinel are ignored and not included in the calculation.
      Returns:

    • sumSquaredError

      public static float sumSquaredError(float[] a, float sentinel, int centralPixIdx)
      Determine the sum squared error within this array using auto-correlation and a self reference value of the item at centralPixIdx in a. Any item in a having value sentinel is ignored and not included in the calculation.
      Returns:

    • lexicographicallyOrderPointsBySort

      public static LinkedHashSet<algorithms.util.PairInt> lexicographicallyOrderPointsBySort(Set<algorithms.util.PairInt> points)
           order points such that:
        q  p : (i_q < i_p)  ((i_q == i_p) (j_q < j_p))

          (-1, 1)
          (-1, 0)   p=(0,  0)
          (-1,-1)     (0, -1)
      runtime complexity is 2*O(N_points) + O(N_points * lg2(O(N_points)))
      Parameters:
      points -
      Returns:

    • lexicographicallyOrderPointsByScan

      public static LinkedHashSet<algorithms.util.PairInt> lexicographicallyOrderPointsByScan(Set<algorithms.util.PairInt> points, int w, int h)
           order points such that:
        q  p : (i_q < i_p)  ((i_q == i_p) (j_q < j_p))

          (-1, 1)
          (-1, 0)   p=(0,  0)
          (-1,-1)     (0, -1)
      runtime complexity is O(w*h)
      Parameters:
      points -
      w -
      h -
      Returns:

      public static boolean areEqual(double[][] a, double[][] b, double tol)
      if a and b are same size and ae element-wise equal within tol, returns true, else false
      Parameters:
      a - array a to compare with b
      b - array b to oompare with a
      tol - the amount that abs(a[i] - b[i]) must be less than or equal to be considered equal.
      Returns:
